infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface ChannelCalculatorCommon

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculator, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, TransferEntropyCalculator, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian, ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov, ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2, MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon, TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlain, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlainIterators, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSeparate, TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo, TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic, TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo, TransferEntropyCommon

    public interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
    A basic interface for calculators computing measures on a channel from a source to a destination time-series (i.e. mutual information and transfer entropy). In the following, we refer to the abstract measure computed by this calculator as the "channel measure".

    The interface is abstract because further specification is required for addObservations or setObservations methods showing whether this is a univariate (ChannelCalculator) or multivariate ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate measure.

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String);
    3. Initialise the calculator using initialise() or other initialise methods defined by child classes;
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • a "setObservations" method (defined by child classes) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to "addObservations" methods (defined by children), then
        3. finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average of the channel measure: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local channel measure values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local channel measure values for a specific set of samples: "computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations" (to be defined by child classes);
      • the distribution of the channel measure values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between source and destination values: computeSignificance(int) or computeSignificance(int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate

      • initialise

        void initialise()
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for (re-)use, with the existing (or default) values of parameters.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        No general properties are defined at the interface level here, i.e. there are only properties defined by child interfaces and classes.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • startAddObservations

        void startAddObservations()
        Signal that we will add in the samples for computing the PDF from several disjoint time-series or trials via calls to "addObservations" rather than "setObservations" type methods (defined by the child interfaces and classes).

      • finaliseAddObservations

        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.

      • getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet

        boolean getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet()
        Query whether the user has added more than a single observation set via the startAddObservations(), "addObservations" (defined by child interfaces and classes), finaliseAddObservations() sequence.
        Returns:
        true if more than a single observation set was supplied

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the channel measure from the previously-supplied samples.
        Returns:
        the estimate of the channel measure
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the channel measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value. (Precise null hypothesis varies between MI and TE).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate AIS calculations.

        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the channel measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value. (Precise null hypothesis varies between MI and TE).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the source values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • setDebug

        void setDebug(boolean debug)
        Set or clear debug mode for extra debug printing to stdout
        Parameters:
        debug - new setting for debug mode (on/off)

      • getLastAverage

        double getLastAverage()
        Return the channel measure last calculated in a call to computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or computeLocalOfPreviousObservations() after the previous initialise() call.
        Returns:
        the last computed channel measure value

      • getNumObservations

        int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to #setObservations(double[]), #addObservations(double[]) etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (e.g. for transfer entropy, where we need to accumulate a number of samples for the past history of the destination).

        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
